item.title: Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HDFS
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification

Following blogs are intended to cover the objective of Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification exam.
  1. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HDFS
  2. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - MapReduce
  3. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - YARN
  4. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Pig
  5. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Hive
  6. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HBase
  7. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Workflow

Disclaimer

This series of blog is only intended to help you prepare for the Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification. Use this series as one of your sources to prepare for the certification exam.

HDFS

HDFS is the default filesystem comes with Hadoop. HDFS stands for Hadoop Distributed Filesystem. HDFS is an integral part of Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification. In this part, I will cover the following objectives of the Certification:
  • Understand how the NameNode maintains the filesystem metadata
  • Understand how data is stored in HDFS
  • Understand the WebHDFS commands
  • Understand the hadoop fs command
  • Understand the relationship between NameNodes and DataNodes
  • Understand the relationship between NameNodes and namespaces in Hadoop 2.0
  • Understand how HDFS Federation works in Hadoop 2.0
  • Understand the various components of NameNode HA in Hadoop 2.0

HDFS Design

HDFS is designed for:
  • storing large files
  • streaming access to stored files
  • storing these files on commodity hardware.
HDFS is not designed for:
  • lots of large files
  • low latency access

NameNodes and DataNodes

HDFS has a master/slave architecture. An HDFS cluster consists of a single NameNode, a master server that manages metadata of files and number of DataNodes which contains the actual file contents. Here are the points which needs to be aware of for the exam.
  • The data is stored on DataNodes in different blocks. Block is the unit of storage. The default size of block is 128 megabyte. The default block size can be configured as dfs.blocksize property.
  • The file contents are distributed in multiple blocks, multiple blocks of a one file can be stored on multiple DataNodes.
  • The blocks are replicated to provide fault-tolerance and availability. The replication factor is configured using dfs.replication property. The default value is 3.
  • NameNode maintains the filesystem tree and metadata for all the files and directories in the tree. NameNode also knows the DataNodes on which all the blocks for a given file are located. NameNode does not store block locations in DataNodes. NameNodes stores all metadata and namespace in two files, i.e. fsimage and edit log.
  • NameNodes are single point of failure in cluster. Secondary NameNode is not a NameNode but responsible for merging the namespace image with edit log. With Secondary NameNode, upon NameNode failure, user only lose the information which is not merged to edit logs.
  • DataNode has the feature to cache the frequently used blocks in memory called block cache.
  • As NameNode manages the namespace and metadata, it is responsible for opening, closing and renaming files and directories
  • DataNodes are responsible of read and writes access as well as block creation, deletion and replication upon request from NameNode.
  • Data Integrity is maintained by keeping a checksum of each block and checksum is computed and matched when the data is retrieved from DataNode.

Steps To Access Data On DataNode

  • A client application sends a request to the NameNode that specifies where they want to put the file in the file system.
  • The NameNode determines how the data is broken down into blocks and which DataNodes will be used to store those blocks. 
  • That information is given to the client application.
  • The client application communicates directly with each DataNode, writing the blocks onto the DataNode.
  • The DataNode then replicates the newly-created block to 2 others DataNodes (assuming the replication factor is 3).

HDFS Federation In Hadoop 2.0

Prior Than Hadoop 2.0

In prior than Hadoop 2.0, HDFS architecture allows single namespace for the entire cluster. A single NameNode manages this namespace. Following diagram (from apache hadoop) shows single namespace architecture.

HDFS Federation

With single namespace, it was very difficult to manage large set of files and directories. To address this limitation, HDFS Federation is introduced in Hadoop 2.0 which supports multiple NameNodes/Namespaces. Following diagram (from apache hadoop) describes the new architecture.


Following points are important for the certification exam.
  • Federation scale the service horizontally, each NameNode/Namespace are independent and don't communicate.
  • DataNodes are common to all NameNodes and DataNodes register themselves with all NameNodes
  • Block pools are the set of blocks belongs to a single namespace and are managed by DataNodes.
  • Namespace along with its block pool is called Namespace volume and is managed as a unit. i.e. deletion of namespace will delete the data blocks as well.
  • Federation provides following benefits
    • Scalability: Namespace can be scaled horizontally by adding NameNodes when storages is scaled.
    • Performance: By distributing the namespaces to multiple namespaces increase the throughput of read/write operations.
    • Isolation: By having multiple namespaces, data can be isolated by managing it by independent namespaces.
  • Federated name services are configured using dfs.nameservices property. The value is a comma separated namespace suffixes which can be used to define other properties belong to each namespace/namenode.
  • To access a federated HDFS cluster, clients use client-side mount tables to map file paths to namenodes. This is managed in configuration using ViewFileSystem and the viewfs:// URIs.

NameNode HA In Hadoop 2.0

NameNode is a single point of failure and if NameNode goes down for any reason (maintenance or failure), the cluster will no be available for any read or write operations. To bring NameNode back alive, it requires tedious effort and long recovery time.
To solve this problem, NameNode HA (High Availability) feature is introduced in Hadoop 2.0. In HA architecture, two NameNodes are configured, one of them is active and the other will be standby NameNode. Upon failure of active NameNode, standby NameNode becomes active and serves the requests.
Followings are the points to remember for certification exam:
  • There are two choices for HA feature, i.e. NFS filer and QJM (quorum journal manager). QJM is recommended choice.
  • QJM runs a group of journal nodes, typically three to record the edit. Active NameNode writes to journal nodes while standby node reads the log from journal nodes. At a time only one node can write to journal nodes.
  • DataNodes send block reports to both NameNodes.
  • Secondary NameNode role is taken by standby NameNode which takes periodic checkpoints of namespace.
  • By default transition of active NameNode to standby NameNode is manual by it can automated by using failover controller (Zookeeper Instances) which requires separate configuration and setup.

hadoop fs Command

HDFS comes up with File System shell. The shell includes many commands to interact with HDFS. The shell can be executed by following two ways:

hadoop fs [options]    deprecated

   hdfs dfs [options]       recommended

All the commands take URIs as arguments. The URI format is scheme://authority/path. The scheme and authority are optional and default scheme is used if not provided. 
To get familiar with all the commands, visit HDFS File System I will explain the subset here.

appendToFile

Append single src or multiple srcs from local file system to the destination file system. It also reads input from stdin and appends to destination file system.

Usage:
hdfs dfs -appendToFile ...
Example:
hdfs dfs -appendToFile localfile1 localfile2 /user/hadoop/hadoopfile

count

Count the number of files, directories and bytes under the paths that match the specific file pattern.

Usage:
hdfs dfs -count [-q] [-h]

Example:
hdfs dfs -count -q -h hdfs://nn1.example.com/file1

du

Displays sizes of files and directories contained in the given directory or the length of a file in case its just a file.

Usage:
hdfs dfs -du [-s] [-h] URI [URI ...]

Example:
hdfs dfs -du /user/hadoop/dir1 /user/hadoop/file1 hdfs://nn.example.com/user/hadoop/dir1

expunge

Empty the trash.

Usage:
hdfs dfs -expunge

setrep

Changes the replication factor of a file. If path is a directory then the command recursively changes the replication factor of all files under the directory tree rooted at path.

Usage:
hdfs dfs -setrep [-R] [-w]
Example:
hdfs dfs -setrep -w 3 /user/hadoop/dir1

touchz

Create a file of zero length.

Usage:
hdfs dfs -touchz URI [URI ...]
Example:
hdfs dfs -touchz pathname

WebHDFS Command

The HTTP REST API exposed by the WebHDFS protocol makes it easier for other languages to interact with HDFS. Note that the HTTP interface is slower than the native Java client, so should be avoided for very large data transfers if possible. Embedded web servers in the namenode and datanode act as WebHDFS endpoint.
The FileSystem scheme of WebHDFS is "webhdfs://". A WebHDFS FileSystem URI has the following format.

webhdfs://:/

In the REST API, the prefix "/webhdfs/v1" is inserted in the path and a query is appended at the end. Therefore, the corresponding HTTP URL has the following format.

http://:/webhdfs/v1/?op=...

For complete list of supported commands, visit WebHDFS Commands

item.title: Pipes and Filters - The Architectural Pattern
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Pipes and Filters Pattern

So let's start with a definition of Pipes and Filters pattern. According to POSA, The Pipes and Filters architectural pattern provides a structure for the system that process a stream of data. Each processing step (stage) is encapsulated in a filter component. Data is passed through pipes between adjacent filters.

We will cover each part of the definition in detail, so don't worry if you don't understand the definition fully, just read along. My focus will remain on the implementation of this pattern.

Terminology

Before I dive into my specific use case, let's discuss the some of the terminology, used in this pattern.

Data Source:

Data Source is responsible to provide the processing data. It can be a database, a file system or a stream.

Filters

Filters are components which process the data. A filter can extract, transform or refine the input data. The filters can be implemented as a passive or active component. Active filters look for the input data while passive filter wait for other filters to push input data to them. These are concrete implementation 

Pipes 

Pipes components are responsible for connection between filter components, connection between data source and first filter and between last filter and data sinks. Pipes provides the synchronization and buffer between adjacent filters. It can be an in memory data structure or persistent application like database or a queuing system.

 Data Sink

Data sinks are the components where last filter placed the data. Like data source it can a file system, database or an output stream.

Problem at Hand

That's enough theory, let's get into the problem we were solving. In our project, there was a stream of input files which needs to be uploaded in Hadoop cluster for analysis. The input files were exported from different systems in different formats and these files were supplied as delta files which were small in sizes. The size was in KB or even in bytes sometimes. It is a universal truth that Hadoop works better with large files than the small files.
We provided the task to combine the small input files into a reasonable large files along with the metadata of input files and then transport the combined files to Hadoop clusters. 
Pipes and Filters was a perfect architecture for this problem so we went with it. Now we will discuss the design and implementation of this project.

Implementation

  Following diagram shows the design of our solution.

System Tasks' Division Into Processing Stages

We identified four tasks in this system and defined them as a stages/filters in as follows:

FileFinder
This stage is responsible to read the input files from Data Source which was a directory structure accessible to the application. FileFinder continuously reads the Data Source and picks up the input files and prepare them be processed. It is an active filter and it also filters out input files based on certain criteria for invalid files.

Metadata
Metadata stage actively keeps looking into the pipe where FileFinder is placing the input files. Metadata stage creates the metadata of the input file and put the files to next pipe for Merger stage.

Merger
Merger is also implemented as active filter and it merges small input files into a large files. The files are packaged into different formats based on the configurations, the types can avro, parquet and orc.

Transporter
Transporter is responsible to move/copy packaged files to configured Hadoop clusters.

Data Structure Definition To Be Passed Along Each Pipe

We wanted to process each file along with the metadata information. To move file information along with metadata we design a data structure FileProcessingRequest. We also defined different directory structure to keep the files. These directories were call zones, e.g. Inprocess Zone, Metadata Zone, Merger Zone, Failed File Zones. These zones were also useful when application was restarted, all the in-process data can be processed again.

Implementation Of Pipe Connections

All the filters were created as Active filters, hence each filter pulls the data (FileProcessingRequest) from prior pipe and push the output to next pipe. To synchronize between filters, we used in memory BlockingQueue implementations. The BlockingQueue has a benefit of blocking the filters until the data is available in BlockingQueue. This provides a buffer between Filters as well. As files were processed in different stages, the files were moved in different zones along the stages.

Error Handling Design

Error handling was a challenge and we came up with two approaches. First, we defined a Failed Zone which contains all the erroneous files. Admin used to look into the Failed Zone and took proper action as needed. Secondly, we find logs as a global place for all stages. All the logs regarding failed files are reported. We used ELK (Elastic Search, Logstash, Kabana) stack to review and analyze logs. Admins review the dashboard every now and then and take proper actions to alleviate the issues.

Global Configuration

The application heavily relies on configurations. We defined properties files which contains the configuration like Hadoop cluster URL, type of output file, size of output file etc. The configuration is read at the start of the application and cached in memory.

ToDos

Current implementation only defines one pipeline with all the stages. I would prefer to design the application in such a way where multiple pipelines can be configured and processed in parallel.

Source Code

As the source code of our project is not an open source, hence I can't share it. But I found a very close implementation of ours as Apache Commons Pipeline. You may look at it if you are in search of an implementation of Pipes and Filters Pattern.

item.title: Apache Hive Performance Tuning
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Apache Hive

The Apache Hive data warehouse software facilitates querying and managing large datasets residing in distributed storage. Hive provides a mechanism to project structure onto this data and query the data using a SQL-like language called HiveQL. 
We have used Apache Hive in our recent project and I was assigned to tune our application, I started to look into Apache Hive documentation to find the best practices recommended by Hive gurus.

In this post, I am outlining my findings, the post is more advanced and technical so probably, experience with Apache Hive is a prerequisite to get most of this post.

So without further ado, let's jump directly into the patterns, anti patterns and best practices.

Partitions Over Small Tables:

Sometime, it has been seen that we design Hive schema to match our use case and to improve the performance of the queries, multiple tables are used for multiple category. e.g. A new table is created for employees work in a state. So there will be a table Employee_NY for NY based employee and so on so forth.

Hive provides partition concept which is much more optimal than tables described in previous section. With partition, only one table will be designed and table will have a partition on State.
Along with static partition, Hive supports dynamic partitions as well, by default dynamic partition is disabled and can be enabled. Followings are some properties to consider when partitioning is desired.
  • hive.exec.dynamic.partition=true/false is used to enable or disable partitioning, default is false.
  • hive.exec.dynamic.partition.mode=strict/nonstrict (default strict). If value is strict, it is made sure, table has at least one static partition 
  • hive.exec.max.dynamic.partitions.pernode (default value being 100) is the maximum dynamic partitions that can be created by each mapper or reducer node.
  • hive.exec.max.dynamic.partitions (default value being 1000) is the total number of dynamic partitions could be created by one DML.
  • hive.exec.max.created.files (default value being 100000) is the maximum total number of files created by all mappers and reducers.

Over Partitioning:

The partitioning is a useful feature in Hive but over partitioned design can be detrimental for queries. As Hadoop is designed to perform better with millions of large files than billions of small files. So with over partitioning, there will more small files than small large file and this will impact the performance. Secondly, Hadoop creates a separate task to process each file, so the more small files we have the more tasks will be created which in turn will use more resources and deteriorate the performance of the queries.
An ideal partition scheme should not result in too many partitions and their directories, and the files in each directory should be large, some multiple of the file- system block size.

Multi Passes Over Same Data:

Hive provides a feasibility to scan source data once to produce multiple aggregations on the same data. For example, following query scan the employee table once but the data is processed two times.

FROM employee
INSERT OVERWRITE employee_NY SELECT * WHERE state='NY'
INSERT OVERWRITE employee_NJ SELECT * WHERE state='NJ'; 

Partition For All Tables:

This is an interesting pattern where it is recommended to create partitions in intermediate (temporary) tables. ETL processes often create intermediate tables so keeping the partitions across the pipeline is recommended.

Bucketing:

Partitioning a table is a great feature to segregate data and optimize query. But as mention over partitioning can deteriorate the performance of the query. In such situations, Hive provides another technique called "Bucketing" to decompose dataset into manageable parts.
Bucketing used column to bucket on, e.g. if bucketing is configured on employee_id column in employee table then hadoop will take hashcode of employee_id to find the correct bucket and stores the employee records in that bucket. Bucket size is configured at table creation time.


CREATE TABLE employee (employee_id INT, firstName STRING, lastName STRING)  PARTITIONED BY (state STRING) CLUSTERED BY (employee_id) INTO 96 BUCKETS; 

The bucketing is enable by following flag

  • hive.enforce.bucketing = true/false, this is a convenient way to enable bucketing.

Adding Columns To Table:

If new columns are needed to add, those can be added and this feature allows developers to load the updated data into Hive without much trouble. If new column is added, the value for this column for existing rows will be NULL. The new column will always be added at the end of the table.

Compress The Data:

Compression reduces the size of data and hence reduce the IO overhead. Compressed data is CPU intensive which is not an issue in Hadoop ecosystem. Despite CPU overhead, compression works best in most of the scenarios and hence it should be used in almost always.

Look Under The Skin:

Sometime we need to look little closely how Hive execute queries. HiveQL is declarative language and Hive translates Hive queries into Map Reduce jobs. EXPLAIN [query] or EXPLAIN EXTENDED [query] can be used to look into the execution plan of query.

Optimized Joins:

In Hive Map-side joins improve the query performance significantly and hence Map-side joins should be preferred over Reduce-side joins. Two ways to optimize joins are 
  • To know the largest table and put it last in the JOIN clause
  • To user /* streamtable(table_name) */ clause.

Parallel Execution:

As mentioned, Hive translates query into MapReduce jobs. Each job is comprised of different stages. By default these stages runs sequentially. The performance can be increased by enabling the parallel execution of these stages.
  • hive.exec.parallel=true/false (default false)
Remember cluster resources will be utilized more in parallel execution.

Strict Mode:

Hive can execute its query in strict mode by enabling following property
  • hive.mapred.mode=strict
By enabling this property, following type of queries are restricted which improves the resource usage in cluster:
  • Queries on partitioned tables are not permitted unless they include a partition filter in WHERE clause, limiting their scope.
  • The second type of queries which are restricted are those with ORDER BY clause but no LIMIT clause.
  • Third type of query prevented Cartesian product. JOIN without ON clauses will create cartesian product. Hive doesn't optimize WHERE clause as a JOIN operator.

Number Of Reducers:

Following properties are used to tune the number of reducers for Hive jobs.
  • hive.exec.reducers.bytes.per.reducer Default value is 1GB which is optimal for most of the cases but user can tune it based on one's needs.
  • hive.exec.reducers.max it represents maximum number of reducers a Hive job can have. This property is useful where one job sometime exhaust all the resources and other jobs wait for available resources. This  property make sure, such situation doesn't happen.

Single MapReduce For Multiple Group By:

  • hive.multigroupby.singlemr=(true/false) Whether to optimize multi group by query to generate single M/R job plan. If the multi group by query has common group by keys, it will be optimized to generate single M/R job. 

Virtual Columns:

Hive provides two virtual columns: one for the input filename for split and the other for the block offset in the file. These are helpful when diagnosing queries where Hive is producing unexpected or null results. By projecting these “columns,” you can see which file and row is causing problems.
These columns are INPUT__FILE__NAME, BLOCK__OFFSET__INSIDE__FILE.

item.title: Scala Introduction for Java Developers
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

I recently start learning Apache Spark and I figured out Apache Spark can be used in Python, Java and Scala. Scala is the most influential language for Spark. For that reason I stared to learn it. Scala is JVM based language so it resembles with Java a lot, actually all the java code is legal in Scala.

This is just an introduction to Scala and some of its features and it is a very technical overview of Scala features. You will find less theory and more code in this article.

Prerequisite

As this is a technical article, I expect followings as prerequisite to get most of this post.
  • The reader should have programming experience, perferably Java programming. 
  • I have used Eclipse with Scala plugin. The information to install Scala plugin can be found at http://scala-ide.org I have used Eclipse Luna

Setup

To write and execute all the code in this post, I have the setup the followings.
  • I have downloaded Eclipse Luna 
  • I have installed Eclipse Scala plugin
  • I have created new Scala Project, by following the instructions at File --> New --> Scala Project, I have chosen all default options.
  • I have created a package blog and created a new Scala Worksheet "ScalaIntroduction.sc".
Once the project is setup, the structure will be similar to followings.

Hello World

Like any programming, I started with Hello World program in Scala.


// Comment
object ScalaIntroduction {
  println("Welcome to Scala Introduction")        
  
  def main(args: Array[String]) : Unit = {
   println("Hello World!")
  }                                               
  
}
Points To Remember
  • object represents a singleton object. All the methods defined in it are considered as static.
  • All the statements in object are evaluated and executed.
  • Methods are defined using def keyword follows by method name.
  • Parameters to methods are declared in parenthesis, parameter names are declared followed by : and parameter type.
  • In method signature the return type is defined after :, Unit is comparable to void in java and optional.
  • The method body starts after = sign. The curly brackets are optional if method contains only one statement.
  • Each expression ends with ; but ; is optional if you write one statement on each line.
Everything is Object
In Scala everything is an object. There is no primitives. The counterpart to java primitives are objects in Scala, e.g. int primitive in java has Int in Scala.

There Are No Primitives:
var x = (1).+(2)
Points To Remember
  • 1 is an object and it above expression 1 is calling + with second object
  • variables are defined using var keyword followed by variable name.
  • The variable type is optional most of the time but can be provided followed by : after variable name. e.g. var x:Int = 2
  • If variable type is not declared, the type is inferred from expression.
  • Again ; is optional at the end of statement.
Functions Are Objects Too
As a functional programming, Scala treat functions as first class citizens, it means functions can be passed as parameters and can be returned. Such functions are call High Order Functions. I have copied an example from http://scala-ide.org

def oncePerSecond(callback: () =>; Unit) {
 while (true) { callback(); Thread sleep 1000 }
 }                                         
def timeFlies() {
 println("time flies like an arrow...")
 }                                         

oncePerSecond(timeFlies)                          

Points To Remember
  • oncePerSecond function is defined to take a function as a parameter.
  • callback doesn't return any thing so the type is defined () => Unit, left side of => represents the parameters to callback empty in this case, right side of => represents the return type of callback method, Unit in this case.
  • callback function is called by adding the (), this will be filled with parameters if callback takes parameters.
  • Thread sleep 1000 is equal to Thread.sleep(1000)
  • timeFlies is a function which print a string.
  • oncePerSecond(timeFlies) is calling oncePerSecond and using timeFlies as callback function. You probably already noticed when timeFlies is passed as function it doesn't contain the ().
Classes
Scala is an object oriented program and classes comes to mind when we think about OOP.

Classes are defined as follows



class Person(first:String, last: String, middle: String) {
 def this(first:String, last: String) {
  this(first, last, "")
  }
  
 def firstName = first;
 def lastName = last;
 def middleName = middle;
 
 
 
 def printLastName(prefix: String) = {
  println(lastName)
 }
 
 
}
Points To Remember
  • class is defined as className followed by parameters to the constructor.
  • this denotes a constructor of class
  • Each parameter is accessed by def function.
  • New function in Class can be added using def statement.
  • The objects of class can be created using new operator as in java.
Inheritance
Inheritance is similar to Java with minor difference which I will explain with the example below.

object ScalaIntroduction {
 val manager = new Manager("001")          
 manager.printTitle                        
 manager.employeeId                        
 
}


abstract class Employee(id : String){
  
  def employeeId : String = id
  def printTitle
  
  
}


class Manager(id : String) extends Employee (id : String) {
 
  def printTitle = {
    println("Manager");
  }
  
  override def employeeId : String = {
    println("Manager Id");
    "Manager-"+id
  }
}
Points To Remember
  • Like java abstract classes has abstract keyword in their definition.
  • function definition can have a body or no body (abstract methods)
  • Subclasses can be defined using "extends" keyword
  • In subclasses, abstract methods are implemented as a regular method definition.
  • If you need to override a method in your subclass, you need to prefix your method definition with override keyword.
Packages and Import
Packages are same as used in Java. Import statements can be little different. Followings are some of the examples of import statements.

import packageName.className
import packageName.{className1, className2}
import packageName._

Points To Remember
  • Single class import works just as in Java
  • Multiple classes can be imported from a package.
  • _ represents wildcard imports, * is used Java
  • Following are imported in Scala program by default
    • All members of package scala
    • All members of package java.lang
    • All members of object scala.Predef
Scala Class Hierarchy
Points To Remember
  • Any is super type of all classes.
  • AnyRef is an alias to java.lang.Object
  • AnyVal is the super type for all primitive type classes. These are not primitive.
  • Null is subtype of all classes and null is represented as in Java
  • Null is not compatible with AnyVal and it's subtypes
  • Nothing is subtype of everything in Java
  • Nothing is usually used to abnormal termination or/and as an element of empty collection. e.g. empty list of String will have Nothing element.
  • Like java primitives (classes in Scala) can be converted, dotted arrow represents conversion capability in above mention picture.
Traits
Traits in Scala were new to me, actually traits are a combination of abstract class and Interface in java. Java 8 interface are similar to traits in Scala.

object ScalaIntroduction {
  println("Welcome to the Scala worksheet")       
  
  val personalExpense = new PersonalExpernseReport(100, 45);
                                                  
 personalExpense.printBalance              
  
}

class PersonalExpernseReport(rev : Double, exp : Double) extends Printer with ExpenseReport{

 def revenue : Double = rev
 def expense : Double = exp
 
 def printBalance = {
  this.print(balance)
 }
 
}

class Printer {

def print(value : Double) = println(value);
}

trait ExpenseReport {
def revenue : Double
def expense : Double

def balance = revenue - expense
}
Points To Remember
  • traits are similar to abstract class and Interface
  • Like abstract class, it can have both concrete and abstract methods.
  • Like Interfaces in  java, a class can use multiple traits using with keyword, e.g. see PersonalExpenseReport class 
  • If class doesn't extends any class then trait will be used with extends clause rather than with clause
  •  trait can not have parameter unlike abstract class where constructor can have parameters.
Type Parameterization Or Generics
Type Parameterization is similar to Java's generics concepts, the only difference is instead of <>, scala uses []

trait List[T] {
 def isEmpty : Boolean
 def head : T
}
Points To Remember
  • Scala uses [] to declare or use parameterized objects. In above code a trait is define of type T.
  • There are upper bound and lower parameter in which only subtype or super type can be passed.
  • >: is used for super type and <: for="" subtypes.="">
  • The Liskov Substitution Principle is worth looking into.
Pattern Matching and Case Classes

trait Expr
case class Number(n: Int) extends Expr
case class Sum(e1: Expr, e2: Expr) extends Expr

def eval(e: Expr): Int = e match {
case Number(n) => n
case Sum(e1, e2) => eval(e1) + eval(e2)
}
Points To Remember

  • A case class definition is similar to a normal class definition, except that it is preceded by the modifier case.
  • case class is similar to pojo in java.
  • new operator can be skipped to create new object of class. e.g. Number(1) is valid statement to create object of Number class mentioned in above example.
  • Pattern matching is a generalization of switch from Java to class hierarchies.
  • Pattern Matching is implemented in Scala using match keyword as shown in above code.
  • match is followed by a sequence of cases, pat => expr.
  • Each case associates an expression expr with a pattern pat.
  • A MatchError exception is thrown if no pattern matches the value of the selector.
  • Patterns are constructed from 
    • constructors, e.g. Number, Sum,
    • variables, e.g. n, e1, e2,
    • wildcard patterns _,
    • constants, e.g. 1, true.
Collections
Scala has a very strong collection of Collections. I will be discussing immutable collections.

Lists

object ScalaIntroduction {

val states = List("NY", "NJ", "NC", "MA", "VA", "CA")

 states.sorted                                    
// res0: List[String] = List(CA, MA, NC, NJ, NY, VA)

 states.length                                    
// res1: Int = 6

 states.last                             
// res2: String = CA
         

 val missingLastElment = states.init              
// missingLastElment  : List[String] = List(NY, NJ, NC, MA, VA)
 
 states.take(3)                                   
// res3: List[String] = List(NY, NJ, NC)
 states.drop(2)                                   
// res4: List[String] = List(NC, MA, VA, CA)
 states(0)                                        
// res5: String = NY
 
 // concatenation of list
 
 states.updated(1, "TX")                          
//> res6: List[String] = List(NY, TX, NC, MA, VA, CA)
 
 states.indexOf("TX", 0)                          
// res7: Int = -1

// creates a pair (List[String], List[String])
states.splitAt(3)                                
// res8: (List[String], List[String]) = (List(NY, NJ, NC),List(MA, VA, CA))

// call a function which is performed on each element of list
 states.map { x => "US."+x }                      
// res9: List[String] = List(US.NY, US.NJ, US.NC, US.MA, US.VA, US.CA)  

states.filter { x => x.startsWith("N") } 
 // res10: List[String] = List(NY, NJ, NC)
}
Points To Remember
  • Practice and explore more methods in List
Other Collections
Scala provides rich set of collections classes to use. Following diagrams show the hierarchy of Immutable and Mutable collection classes or traits. courtesy to http://docs.scala-lang.org


mutable Collections
Immutable Collections

Enjoy Coding.... 
Disclaimer
I have used the examples given at https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005 or at http://www.scala-lang.org/

item.title: Apache Kafka Concepts in Q&A form
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
What is Kafka?

Kafka is a distributed, partitioned, replicated commit log service. It provides the functionality of a messaging system, but with a unique design.

What is a commit log?

A log is storage abstraction. It is an append-only, totally-ordered sequence of records ordered by time. Following diagram explains the log storage.

Records are appended to the end of the log, and reads proceed left-to-right. Each entry is assigned a unique sequential log entry number.

What are the components in Kafka system?
Producer
Consumer
Topic
Kafka Cluster
Broker


What are Topics?


  • A topic is a category or feed name to which messages are published.
  • Kafka cluster uses partitioned log for each topic.
  • Each message in partition is uniquely identified by a sequential id called offset.
  • Kafka cluster retains all message for a configurable retention time, after that retention time messages are deleted.
  • Consumer keeps the state of the message and each consumer has its own offset in the log.
  • Consumer can reprocess a message by resetting offset to previous message.
  • Each partition must fit in a single server but partitions for topics can exists on multiple servers.
  • Partitions are replicated across servers for fault tolerance.
  • Each partition has a leader server which active read and write the data and zero or more follower servers which passively replicate the data. If  a leader dies, one of the follower becomes the leader.

What are Producers?


  • Producers publish data to the topics of their choice. 
  • The producer is responsible for choosing which message to assign to which partition within the topic.

Consumers

  • Each consumer is labeled with a consumer group
  • Kafka broadcast messages to one consumer in each consumer group.

Broker

Kafka runs in a cluster of one or more server, each server is called a broker.

Parallel Consumption of Messages:

  • Parallelism is achieved by assigning the partitions in the topic to the consumers in the consumer group so that each partition is consumed by exactly one consumer in the group.
  • To achieve parallelism, it should be made sure there consumers are equal or less than partitions.
  • Kafka only provides a total order over messages within a partition, not between different partitions in a topic. 

Hello World Example

Kafka Download

Download Kafka from downloads as gzip file
Extract gzip file and let's call the unzipped directory as  KAFKA_HOME
change directory to KAFKA_HOME.

Start Server

Start Zookeeper 


bin/zookeeper-server-start.sh config/zookeeper.properties

Start Server

bin/kafka-server-start.sh config/server.properties

Create the topic

bin/kafka-topics.sh --create --zookeeper localhost:2181 --replication-factor 1 --partitions 1 --topic test


Sending Message

bin/kafka-console-producer.sh --broker-list localhost:9092 --topic test

kaka-console-producer.sh provides to send messages from console.

Starting Consumer

bin/kafka-console-consumer.sh --zookeeper localhost:2181 --topic test --from-beginning

similar to console producer, console consumer is used to consume the message on console.


NOTE:

All these notes I took while I was reading official documentation of Apache Kafka.

item.title: Introduction to Hadoop
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Hadoop:
Hadoop is a Apache project. It is software library which provides implementation to deal with big data in distributed environment.

Hadoop has following component
  • Hadoop Common: The common utilities that support the other Hadoop modules. Still investigating..
  • Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS™): A distributed file system that provides high-throughput access to application data.
    • To deal with Big Data, a different file system is needed and hadoop came up with HDFS. There are certain commands which I learnt while creating files in this HDFS. The Hadoop is formatted using /etc/local/hadoop/bin/hdfs namenode -format to create HDFS
    • Commands from following link are used to manage HDFS http://hadoop.apache.org/docs/current/hadoop-project-dist/hadoop-common/FileSystemShell.html

  • Hadoop YARN: A framework for job scheduling and cluster resource management.
  • Hadoop MapReduce: A YARN-based system for parallel processing of large data sets. MapReduce is a design pattern created by google and implemented by Hadoop to make it easy for developers to work with Big Data.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks for sharing your informative article on Hive ODBC Driver. Your article is very descriptive and assists me to learn whole concept in detail. Hadoop Training in Chennai | Big Data Training in Chennai

item.title: Hadoop Installation
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Ok, I decided to learn Hadoop and I started with http://hadoop.apache.org .

The preferred Operating System for Hadoop is Linux and hence I decided to install Ubuntu 14.04 LTS in VirtualBox. 

After this installation, i tried the basic steps provided at http://hadoop.apache.org but i really got the working environment. Then http://dogdogfish.com/2014/04/26/installing-hadoop-2-4-on-ubuntu-14-04/ was rescue.
I followed the steps provided in this blog and volla the environment was ready to play with.

Here is the summary of my steps:
0) Installed Java 1.7 and export JAVA_HOME in ~/.bashrc class
1) Downloaded Hadoop 2.4 and extracted it as /etc/local/hadoop (using sudo ofcourse)
2) Created hadoop group and hduser user in Ubuntu.
3) Change the ownership of /etc/local/hadoop to hduser
sudo addgroup hadoop
sudo adduser --ingroup hadoop hduser
sudo adduser hduser sudo
sudo chown -R hduser:hadoop /usr/local/hadoop/
4) setup ssh 
ssh-keygen -t rsa -P ""
cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys

5) Set the following flags in /etc/sysctl.conf

net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 = 1
net.ipv6.conf.default.disable_ipv6 = 1
net.ipv6.conf.lo.disable_ipv6 = 1
 
6) make a dir /usr/local/hadoop/data/
7) update following files

1.) /usr/local/hadoop/etc/hadoop/hadoop-env.sh
Change export JAVA_HOME=${JAVA_HOME} to match the JAVA_HOME you set in your bashrc (for us JAVA_HOME=/usr).
Also, change this line:
export HADOOP_OPTS="$HADOOP_OPTS -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true
to be

export HADOOP_OPTS="$HADOOP_OPTS -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true -Djava.library.path=$HADOOP_PREFIX/lib"
And finally, add the following line:
export HADOOP_COMMON_LIB_NATIVE_DIR=${HADOOP_PREFIX}/lib/native
2.) /usr/local/hadoop/etc/hadoop/yarn-env.sh
Add the following lines:

export HADOOP_CONF_LIB_NATIVE_DIR=${HADOOP_PREFIX:-"/lib/native"}
export HADOOP_OPTS="-Djava.library.path=$HADOOP_PREFIX/lib"
3.) /usr/local/hadoop/etc/hadoop/core-site.xml
Change the whole file so it looks like this:

  <value>hdfs://localhost:9000</value>
</property>
<property>
  <name>hadoop.tmp.dir</name>
  <value>/usr/local/hadoop/data</value>
</property>
</configuration>
4.) /usr/local/hadoop/etc/hadoop/mapred-site.xml
Change the whole file so it looks like this:

5.) /usr/local/hadoop/etc/hadoop/hdfs-site.xml
Change the whole file so it looks like this:

6.) /usr/local/hadoop/etc/hadoop/yarn-site.xml
Change the whole file so it looks like this:

        <value>localhost:8030</value>

    </property>
</configuration>

8) format the hdfs
/etc/local/hadoop/hadoop namenode -format

9) Start the dfs
/etc/local/hadoop/sbin/start-dfs.sh

I am still figuring out all above options and will explain them in future blogs

item.title: Oozie Refresher
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: Oozie Workflow Action a single unit of work which can be performed by execution engine. Workflow is created in workflow.xml, contains action and control nodes. a control-dependency DAG of actions Coordinator Definitions of data sets or scheduler which triggers workflow Bundle Collection of coordinators Oozie components A workflow engine A scheduler Rest API Command line client Bundles Backend Database workflow.xml contains the definition of a workflow and it should reside on Hdfs job configurations are supplied to Oozie server to kick off the job. Oozie starts all job by initiating a launcher job which is a mapper job. Workflow Patterns

item.title: HDP Certified Developer (HDPCD) Exam - Data Ingestion
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
HDP Certified Developer

This is first post from HDPCD exam preparation series. In this post, I will discuss and solve tasks regarding data ingestion part of the exam.

Certified Badge shows my badge from Hortonworks.

Prerequisite

This series is heavily influenced by Hortonworks practice exam. You may follow the instruction to setup environment at Practice Exam. You can also learn from this series if you have an existing Hadoop environment. You can also download Hortonworks sandbox and can install it on your computer for local setup. You can find instructions to download and install at Hortoworks Sandbox. In case you choose to use Hortonworks sandbox or an existing environment, I have provide the dataset along with solutions to tasks at HDPCD-Certification. Environment prepared through Practice Exam instructions already have dataset but you would need to download the solutions if you want to. This is a very hands-on series, so roll sleeves and get ready to keep your hands dirty.

Task 00

In this task, we will download the datasets for our next tasks. The datasets along with solutions will be downloaded from HDPCD Certification. You can download the contents as a zip file by clicking Download ZIP button once you are on HDPCD Certification page. Once you download the contents, unzip it in your home directory.

Task 01

As the dataset is downloaded, in this task, we will upload dataset into hadoop using hdfs commands. To see the details of this task, look into /home/horton/HDPCD-Certification-master/data_Ingestion/Task01. The problem can be solved by running following commands. 
cd /home/horton/HDPCD-Certification-master
hdfs dfs -put datasets/flightdelays

Task 02

In this task, we will be ingesting data using Apache Flume. The task detail is given in/home/horton/HDPCD-Certification-master/data_Ingestion/Task02. Flume requires a file which contains the ingestion flow. I have created a configuration file for this task at and we will need to run flume agent as follows: 
cd /home/horton/HDPCD-Certification-master/data_Ingestion/solutions

flume-ng agent --name a1 --conf-file Task02.conf
This will start a flume agent and it will ingest data into hadoop. Don't forget to stop the agent by pressing Ctrl+c. In source directory, all ingested files will be suffixed by .COMPLETED.

Task 03

In Task03 we will be exporting data from hadoop to a relational database using Apache Sqoop. You need to make sure you create a table in relational database before starting export. I have been using environment suggested for Practice Exam and database setup exists in. First we will copy a file into hadoop which will be exported to relational database. 
hdfs dfs -mkdir weather 
cd /home/horton/HDPCD-Certification-master 
hdfs dfs -put datasets/flightdelays/sfo_weather.csv
Now as the data is ingested in hadoop, we are ready to execute sqoop command. The command is give in solutions directory as Task03.sh as 
sqoop export --connect jdbc:mysql://namenode/flightinfo --username root --password hadoop --table weather --export-dir /user/horton/weather --input-fields-terminated-by ','
This will export data in weather table in flightinfo database. If process runs without any errors, you can view the exported data in mysql database.

Task 04

Now we will be performing the opposite of Task03. In this task we will be importing data from mysql table to hadoop. As we are using the same setup as Task03 has, no extra setup is required. The export command is given in solutions directory as Task04.sh as 
sqoop import --connect jdbc:mysql://namenode/flightinfo --username root --password hadoop --query 'SELECT * FROM weather WHERE $CONDITIONS' --split-by year --target-dir /user/horton/sqoopImport
Here data is imported using a query but you can choose table, column and where command options to mimic the command as well.

Summary

In this session, we ingested data using hdfs command, flume and sqoop utilities. Now we are ready to move to next section of certfication where ingested data will be transformed using Pig.

Tips

  • Open one command terminal with three tabs
    • a tab to run commands
    • a tab to edit solution files
    • a tab to run any hdfs command
  • Exam environment comes with web links to documentation of Pig, Hive, Flume and Sqoop. You may open all these links in one web browser window to save time.

item.title: HDP Certified Developer (HDPCD) Exam - Data Transformation
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
HDP Certified Developer Exam

This series explains some of the tasks which you may be performing in this exam. I have covered Data Ingestion section in previous session, now we will talk about next section, i.e. Data Transformation

Prerequisite

You will need to complete Data Ingestion session which make datasets available for this session. Let's start our tasks for this session.

Task05

In this task, following components of Pig are covered. Read their documentation if you need to
  • LOAD operator
  • FILTER operator
  • FOREACH...GENERATE operator
  • STORE Operator
The task detail and solutions are given in github repository. The solution can be run as follows: 
pig -f Task05.pig
Here we are placing all pig commands in Task05.pig file and then running it as pig script.

Task 06

This task has three parts and each part covers particular pig operator and requirement for the certification

Part1

In this part, you will learn the GROUP BY and COUNT operator along with FOREACH...GENERATE

Part2

FILTER BY, COUNT and FOREACH...GENERATE will be used in this exercise.

Part3

FILTER BY, COUNT and FOREACH...GENERATE will be used in this part.

Task07 & Task08

These two task should be considered as one task as Task07 prepares data for Task08. In this exercise, the data will be loaded from a Hive table. You will use special load function org.apache.hive.hcatalog.pig.HCatLoader() to load the data from Hive. I have noticed, most of examples given online are using this function without hive word, which may be the package before HCatalog became part of Hive project. Another take away is, when pig uses HCatalog to load data from Hive, extra flag -useHCatalog needs to provide e.g 
pig -useHCatalog -f Task08.pig

Task09

In this task, we will practice JOIN operator between two relations in pig. Different join operators are supported but inner join will be suffice to clear the certification exam. The requirement and solution for this task can be found at Task09

Summary

With these tasks we have covered Data Transformation section for Certification exam. Please note all the solutions are given as pig script and you can run them as 
pig -f <solutionFile>
By default pig runs job as mapreduce jobs, we can change mapreduce execution engine to tez execution engine by providing -x option as follows: 
pig -x tez -f <solutionFile>

item.title: HDP Certified Developer (HDPCD) Exam - Data Analysis
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
HDP Certified Developer Exam

This series explains some of the tasks which you may be performing in this exam. I have covered Data Ingestion section in previous session, now we will talk about next section, i.e. Data Analysis

Prerequisite

You will need to complete Data Ingestion session which make datasets available for this session. Data Analysis will use Apache Hive project to work with transformed data.

Task10

In this task, existing Hive table will be analyzed by using UDF (AVG). Simple hive queries will be constructed.

Task11

In this task, we will learn how to create ORC and textFile based Hive tables. Data will be loaded from local system and data will be transformed from one table to another. Requirement and solution are given at github

Task12

This task will cover following topics
  • How to run Hive queries with multiple execution engine, mapreduce and tez.
  • How to join multiple tables.
  • How to select subset of columns from joined tables.
The requirement and solution can be found at github

Task13

This tasks covers following topics:
  • How to create a partitioned hive table
  • How to insert data in partitioned table.
  • How to store the data in ORC format and text format.

Summary

Apache Hive has been used in this section. The hive scripts can be used to run multiple hive queries with one command like 
hive -f <hiveScript>
Hive individual query can be run with -e options as 
hive -e "<HIVE Query>"
These tasks have helped me to prepare for certification and I believe if you understand and can complete these tasks within 2 hours, you can clear the exam as well.

item.title: HDP Certified Developer (HDPCD) Exam - Data Transformation
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Prerequisite

  1. To follow the instructions in this blog, make sure you have installed Hortonworks sandbox. You may find the instructions to install and launch the Hortonworks sandbox at Install Hortonworks Sandbox.
  2. Make sure you have downloaded the sample data to Hortonworks sandbox from Excercises With Data.

Category

HDP Certified Developer Exam is divided in three categories. These categories are 
  • Data Ingestion
  • Data Transformation
  • Data Analysis
In this blog, we will discuss Data Transformation category.

Tasks

Each category is divided into multiple tasks. I will explain each task in this section. Most of these tasks will talk about Apache Pig and Apache Hive. To learn about them, please visit Apache Pig and Apache Hive.

Write and Execute a Pig Script

Pig script is a text file (usually has .pig extension but it is not required) which contain Pig Latin statements.
Download the Excercises With Data
  • change directory to data_transformation folder in downloaded folder.
  • run pig -x local SchoolsNJ.pig
  • SchoolsNJ.pig reads Schools.csv file and prints NJ schools.

Load data into a Pig relation with/without a schema

  • LOAD statement is used to load data into a pig relation.
  • LOAD 'data' [USING function] [AS schema] is the syntax. The sections in brackets are optional.
  • LOAD can load a single file or all files in a directory.
  • If no schema is defined the columns are of bytearray type.

Loading data with schema

  • change directory to data_transformation folder in downloaded folder.
  • run pig -x local SalarySchema.pig
  • SalarySchema.pig loads Salaries.csv using a schema and displays the schema on console.
