item.title: Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Pig
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification

Following blogs are intended to cover the objective of Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification exam.
  1. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HDFS
  2. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - MapReduce
  3. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - YARN
  4. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Pig
  5. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Hive
  6. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HBase
  7. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Workflow

Disclaimer

This series of blog is only intended to help you prepare for the Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification. Use this series as one of your sources to prepare for the certification exam.

Pig

Apache Pig is a platform for analyzing large data sets that consists of a high-level language for expressing data analysis programs, coupled with infrastructure for evaluating these programs. Pig's infrastructure layer consists of a compiler that produces sequences of Map-Reduce programs. We will cover following exam objectives in this blog.
  • Differentiate between Pig data types, including the complex types bag, tuple and map
  • Define Pig relations
  • Write a User-Defined Pig Function
  • Invoke a Pig UDF

Pig Data Types

Pig supports following data types.
  • Numeric
    • int
      • 32-bit signed integer
    • long
      • 64-bit singed integer
    • float
      • 32-bit floating point number
    • double
      • 64-bit floating point number
  • Text
    • chararray
      • Character array in UTF-16 format
  • Binary
    • bytearray
      • Byte Array
  • Complex
    • tuple
      • Sequence of fields of any type
    • bag
      • An unordered collection of tuples, possibly with duplicates.
    • map
      • A set of key/value pairs, key must be character array, but values may be of any type.

Pig Relation

In Pig, result of any operator is a relation. Relation is a set of tuples and tuples is just like a row in database table. Tuple contains multiple fields (attributes) in a particular order. Each relation is given an alias which is used to represent all the data in the relation. Relation details can be found by using DESCRIBE command.

Pig User Defined Function

Pig has large number of functions but sometime it is needed to create a custom function to process the data. Pig made it easy to define and use User Defined Function (UDF). UDF can be written in Java, Python or Javascript.
When creating User Defined Function, all UDF directly or indirectly extends EvalFunc class. This class has exec method which needs to be overridden.

public abstract class EvalFunc {
public abstract T exec(Tuple input) throws IOException;
}
 
  • EvalFunc is extended directly or indirectly when UDF is created.
  • exec(Tuple input) is overriden in subclasses.
  • Once UDF is completed, it is packaged in a jar file.
  • Packaged jar file is made available to pig by REGISTER operator
    • REGISTER ;
  • Once UDF is register, it can be invoked in Pig scripts/shell by using UDF's full class name including package.
  • UDF name can be shortened by defining alias, using DEFINE operator
    • DEFINE myFunction full-udf-classname-including-package
  • FilterFunc and LoadFunc are subclasses of EvalFunc which can used if Filter/Load functions are being created.

item.title: Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - YARN
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification

Following blogs are intended to cover the objective of Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification exam.
  1. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HDFS
  2. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - MapReduce
  3. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - YARN
  4. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Pig
  5. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Hive
  6. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HBase
  7. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Workflow

Disclaimer

This series of blog is only intended to help you prepare for the Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification. Use this series as one of your sources to prepare for the certification exam.

YARN

In Hadoop 2.0, a new architecture is introduced which divides two major functions of JobTracker: resource management and job life-cycle management into separate components. This new architecture is called MRv2 or YARN (Yet Another Resource Negotiator). In this blog I will discuss following objectives of Certification Exam.
  • Understand the architecture of YARN
  • Understand the components of the YARN ResourceManager
  • Demonstrate the relationship between NodeManagers and ApplicationMasters
  • Demonstrate the relationship between ResourceManagers and ApplicationMasters
  • Explain The relationship between Containers and ApplicationMasters
  • Explain how Container failure is handled for a YARN MapReduce job

YARN Architecture

In Hadoop 2, the responsibilities of JobTracker is divided into separate components. Following diagram shows the architecture of this new model.

Notes:

  • The ResourceManager (RM) and per-node slave, the NodeManager (NM), form the data-computation framework.
  • ResourceManager provides all the resources required to perform a job.
  • ApplicationMaster is
    • application specific component
    • responsible for negotiating resources from ResourceManager (RM)
    • responsible to work with NodeManager (NM) to execute and monitor tasks.
  • ResourceManager (RM) has two main components
    • Scheduler
    • ApplicationManager
  • Scheduler
    • is responsible for allocating resources to the various running applications.
    • doesn't monitor the running applications
    • doesn't restart failed tasks
    • provides resources in abstract notion called Container which incorporates elements as memory, cpu, disk etc.
    • Scheduler is a pluggable component, i.e. available resource can be assigned based on different algorithms. CapacityScheduler and FairScheduler are example of pluggable schedulers.
  • ApplicationManager
    • is responsible for accepting job-submission.
    • negotiates the first container for executing application specific ApplicationMaster
    • provides the service for restarting ApplicationMaster container on failure.
  • NodeManager
    • is per-machine framework agent.
    • is responsible for containers, monitoring their usage and reporting back the same to ResourceManager.

YARN Application Lifecycle

  • It all starts with a client submitting a new Application Request to the Resource Manager (RM).
  • The ApplicationsManager (AsM) finds an available NodeManager on the cluster that is not too busy.
  • That node’s NodeManager (NM) creates an instance of the ApplicationMaster (AM).
  • The AM then sends a request to the RM, asking for specific resources like memory and CPU requirements. The RM replies with a list of Containers, which includes the specific NodeManagers to start the Containers on.
  • The AM starts a Container on each NodeManager as instructed by the RM. The Container peforms a task, as directed by the AM.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks for the nice summary about YARN

Appreciating the hard work you put into your website and detailed information you provide. It's awesome to come across a blog every once in a while that isn't the same unwanted rehashed material. Excellent read! I've saved your site and I'm including your RSS feeds to my Google account.
Your style is so unique compared to other people I have read stuff from. Thanks for posting when you have the opportunity, Guess I'll just bookmark this web site.

item.title: Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HBase
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification

Following blogs are intended to cover the objective of Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification exam.
  1. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HDFS
  2. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - MapReduce
  3. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - YARN
  4. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Pig
  5. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Hive
  6. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HBase
  7. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Workflow

Disclaimer

This series of blog is only intended to help you prepare for the Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification. Use this series as one of your sources to prepare for the certification exam.

HBase

HBase is a distributed column-oriented database built on top of HDFS. HBase is the Hadoop application to use when you require real-time read/write random access to very large datasets. In this blog, I will discuss following exam objectives:

  • Use the HBase API to add or delete a row to an HBase table
  • Use the HBase API to retrieve data from an HBase table

Operational API

HBase stores the data in table. Each table consists of rows and columns. Columns are versioned and each column is part of column group/family. Each row can have its own set of columns. HBase exposes Java API to perform operation on HBase tables. Following sections will discuss these API in context of certification exam.

Add/Delete Data In HBase Table

HBase API provides Put and Delete classes to add and delete data from a HBase Table. Following code snippet shows these two classes in action.

HTable table = new HTable(config, "myTable");

// Add Data

byte [] myRow = Bytes.toBytes("myRow");
Put p1 = new Put(row1); 
byte [] databytes = Bytes.toBytes("data");
p1.add(databytes, Bytes.toBytes("colum1"), Bytes.toBytes("value1")); table.put(p1);

// Delete Data

Delete delete = new Delete(Bytes.toBytes("myRow"));
delete.deleteColumn(Bytes.toBytes("ColumnFamily"), Bytes.toBytes("ColumnName"));
delete.deleteFamily(Bytes.toBytes("ColumnFamily"));
table.delete(delete);

Points To Remember

  • The object of org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.HTable created by passing configuration and table name.
  • org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Put is used to add row in HBase table.
  • All the data is added in form of bytes.
  • Column family and column qualifier are set when org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Put is created.
  • Once org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Put is created, the object of org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.HTable is used to create the data.
  • org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Delete is used to perform delete operation on single row.
  • Delete object is instantiated with row to delete an entire row.
  • To delete specific families, execute deleteFamily for each family to delete.
  • To delete multiple versions of specific columns, execute deleteColumns for each column to delete.
  • To delete specific versions of specific columns, execute deleteColumn for each column version to delete.

Retrieve Data From HBase Table

HBase expose two classes to retrieve data from HBase table, i.e. org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Get and org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Scan

Following notes should be kept in mind.
  • org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Get is used to perform Get operations on a single row.
  • To get everything for a row, instantiate a Get object with the row to get. 
  • To get all columns from specific families, execute addFamily for each family to retrieve.
  • To get specific columns, execute addColumn for each column to retrieve.
  • org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Scan is used to perform Scan operations on a HBase table.
  • All operations are identical to Get with the exception of instantiation.
  • org.apache.hadoop.hbase.client.Scan can scan a single row, a set of rows by specifying startRow and stopRow or full table.

item.title: Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Workflow
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification

Following blogs are intended to cover the objective of Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification exam.
  1. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HDFS
  2. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - MapReduce
  3. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - YARN
  4. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Pig
  5. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Hive
  6. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HBase
  7. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Workflow

Disclaimer

This series of blog is only intended to help you prepare for the Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification. There is no guarantee that you will pass the exam with this material only. Use this series as one of your sources to prepare for the certification exam.

MapReduce Workflow

When MapReduce job becomes complex, sometimes it makes sense to divide a large, complex MapReduce job into multiple small MapReduce jobs. These jobs can be executed in a workflow. The modular jobs then can be executed linearly or direct acyclic graph (DAG). In this blog, I will discuss my notes regarding following exam objectives:
  • Understand Oozie workflow actions
  • Deploy Oozie workflows
  • Use the org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.lib.jobcontrol.JobControl class to define a workflow

JobControl

  • JobControl provides a control for a group of jobs.
  • JobControl encapsulates a set of MapReduce jobs and its dependency.
  • JobControl is provided with job configuration and dependencies between jobs and JobControl runs the jobs in dependency order.
  • If a job fails, JobControl won't run its dependencies.
  • JobControl provides APIs for the client app to add a job to the group and to get the jobs in the group in different states.

Apache Oozie

Apache Oozie is a system for running workflows of dependent jobs. It is composed of two main parts: a workflow engine that stores and runs workflows composed of different types of Hadoop jobs (MapReduce, Pig, Hive, and so on), and a coordinator engine that runs workflow jobs based on predefined schedules and data availability.

Oozie runs as a service in the cluster, and clients submit workflow definitions for immediate or later execution. A workflow is a DAG of action nodes and control-flow nodes. An action node performs a workflow task, such as moving files in HDFS, running a MapReduce, Streaming, Pig, or Hive job, performing a Sqoop import, or running an arbitrary shell script or Java program. A control-flow node governs the workflow exe‐ cution between actions by allowing such constructs as conditional logic

  • Workflow definition is provided as workflow.xml
  • is the parent tag in workflow.xml
  • All workflows must have one start and end node.
  • When the workflow job starts, it transitions to the node specified by the start node.
  • A workflow job succeeds when it transitions to the end node. However, if the workflow job transitions to a kill node, it is considered to have failed and reports the appropriate error message specified by the message element in the workflow definition.
  • The optional prepare element runs before the MapReduce job.
  • Oozie supports expression language to interact with workflows. e.g. ${wf:user()}
  • Workflow application can be released by putting workflow definition file workflow.xml and dependent files in lib directory. workflow.xml is placed at the top level of application folder.
  • Oozie provides a command line tool oozie to communicate with Oozie server.
  • oozie command line tool can be used to submit the workflow application.
    • oozie job -config applicationConfigfile -run

item.title: Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - MapReduce
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification

Following blogs are intended to cover the objective of Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification exam.
  1. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HDFS
  2. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - MapReduce
  3. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - YARN
  4. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Pig
  5. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Hive
  6. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - HBase
  7. Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification - Workflow

Disclaimer

This series of blog is only intended to help you prepare for the Hadoop 2.0 Java Developer Certification. Use this series as one of your sources to prepare for the certification exam.

MapReduce

Hadoop MapReduce is a software framework for easily writing applications which process vast amounts of data (multi-terabyte data-sets) in-parallel on large clusters (thousands of nodes) of commodity hardware in a reliable, fault-tolerant manner.
In this part, I will cover following objectives of certification exam:
  • Understand the architecture of MapReduce
  • Understand the various phases of a MapReduce job
  • Demonstrate how key/value pairs flow through a MapReduce job
  • Write Java Mapper and Reducer classes
  • Use the org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Job class to configure a MapReduce job
  • Use the TextInputFormat and TextOutputFormat classes
  • Write a custom InputFormat
  • Configure a Combiner
  • Define a custom Combiner
  • Define a custom Partitioner
  • Use the Distributed Cache
  • Use the CompositeInputFormat class

MapReduce Architecture

Followings are important points to remember:
  • MapReduce jobs contain multiple phases, map and reduce phase stand out.
  • Input dataset is splited into independent chunks and supplied to map tasks which run in parallel
  • The framework sorts the outputs of the maps, which are then input to the reduce tasks. 
  • Typically both the input and the output of the job are stored in a file-system. 
  • The framework takes care of scheduling tasks, monitoring them and re-executes the failed tasks.
  • The MapReduce framework consists of a single master ResourceManager, one slave NodeManager per cluster-node, and MRAppMaster per application.
  • Minimally, applications specify the input/output locations and supply map and reduce functions via implementations of appropriate interfaces and/or abstract-classes. These, and other job parameters, comprise the job configuration.
  • The Hadoop job client then submits the job.
  • MapReduce applications need not be written in Java.

MapReduce Phases

Map Phase

  • Mapper maps input key/value pairs to a set of intermediate key/value pairs.
  • Map tasks run in parallel and independently.
  • Transformed intermediate records do not need to be of same type as the input type records.
  • Mapper phase can output zero or many pairs.
  • Number of map tasks are equal to number of InputSplit generated by InputFormat for the job.
  • Mapper class is configured in job using Job.setMapperClass(mapperClass) method.
  • MapReduce framework calls  map(WritableComparable, Writable, Context) method of Mapper class for each key/value pair in the InputSplit for that task.

Reduce Phase

  • Reducer reduces a set of intermediate values which share a key to a smaller set of values.
  • The number of reduces for the job is set by the user via Job.setNumReduceTasks(int).
  • Reducer class is configured in job using  Job.setReducerClass(Class).
  • Reducer class implements reduce(WritableComparable, Iterable, Context) and framework calls this method for each key, listOfValues of grouped inputs.
  • The output of the reduce task is typically written to the FileSystem via Context.write(WritableComparable, Writable)
  • The output of reducer is not sorted.
  • If no reduction is needed, number of reducers should set to zero.

Shuffle And Sort

  • Shuffle and sort are sub-phases of reduce phase and occur simultaneously.
  • In Shuffle phase the framework fetches the relevant partition of the output of all the mappers, via HTTP.
  • MapReduce framework groups mapper output (reducer input) by keys in Sort phase.
  • Job.setGroupingComparatorClass(Class) can be used to control how intermediate keys are grouped.

Partition

  • The Mapper outputs are sorted and then partitioned per Reducer.
  • The total number of partitions is the same as the number of reduce tasks for the job.
  • HashPartitioner is the default Partitioner, a custom implementation of Partitioner can provided to MapReduce job.

Implementing MapReduce Job

To write a MapReduce job, user need to create a Mapper class, a Reducer class and configuration of Job class and its submission.

Mapper Class

  • User needs to subclass org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Mapper
  • User will override map(KEYIN key, VALUEIN value, org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Mapper.Context context) and provide custom logic in it.
  • cleanup(org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Mapper.Context context) and setup(org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Mapper.Context context) methods can be overridden to setup and cleanup before and after map method.

Reducer Class

  • User needs to subclass org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Reducer.
  • User will override reduce(KEYIN key, Iterable values, org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Reducer.Context context) and provide custom logic in it.
  • cleanup(org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Reducer.Context context) and setup(org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Reducer.Context context) methods can be overridden to setup and cleanup before and after reduce method.

Job Class

  • Job is configured using org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Job.
  • org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Job class has methods to configure Mapper, Reducer, input format, output format etc.
  • Job is submitted by calling job.waitForCompletion(true)
  • Job submission is wrapped in public static void main(String[] args) method which is the starting point of every java class.

Optional Parts

  • Combiner, Partitioner, GroupingComparator are optional part and can be implemented if user wants more control on MapReduce job.

InputFormat and OutputFormat

MapReduce has a simple model of data processing: inputs and outputs for the map and reduce functions are key-value pairs. Mapper take input as a key/value pair and output a key/value pair. Similarly, Reducer take certain key, list and return a key/value pair.
  • TextInputFormat is the default InputFormat if InputFormat is not configured.
  • TextOutputFormat is the default OutputFormat if OutputFormat is not configured.
  • Data is split into multiple InputSplit which represents a chunk of data (collection of key/value pairs). Each map task handle one key/value.
  • InputSplit are created by InputFormat and user doesn't deal with InputSplit directlly.
  • InputFormat provides the RecordReader implementation used to extract input records from the logical InputSplit for processing by the Mapper.
  • FileSplit is the default InputSplit.
  • Some of InputFormat implementations are:
    • org.apache.hadoop.mapred.FileInputFormat
    • org.apache.hadoop.mapred.TextInputFormat
    • org.apache.hadoop.mapred.SequenceFileInputFormat
    • org.apache.hadoop.mapred.lib.CombineFileInputFormat
  • CompositeInputFormat is an InputFormat capable of performing joins over a set of data sources sorted and partitioned the same way.
  • OutputFormat validates the output-specification of the job; for example, check that the output directory doesn't already exist.
  • OutputFormat provides the RecordWriter implementation used to write the output files of the job.
  • OutputCommitter sets up the job, cleans up the job, check if commit is needed, commit the task output and discard the task commit for failed tasks. 
  • FileOutputCommitter is the default OutputCommitter.
  • Some of OutputFormat implementations are:
    • org.apache.hadoop.mapred.TextOutputFormat
    • org.apache.hadoop.mapred.lib.db.DBOutputFormat
    • org.apache.hadoop.mapred.lib.NullOutputFormat
    • org.apache.hadoop.mapred.SequenceFileOutputFormat

Distributed Cache

  • DistributedCache distributes application-specific, large, read-only files efficiently.
  • Archived files are un-archived on slave nodes.
  • When you launch a job, Hadoop copies the files specified by the -files, -archives, and -libjars options to the distributed filesystem (normally HDFS).
  • Node manager is responsible for copying the file from distributed filesystem to local disk for tasks (map/reduce) to access them locally.
  • Files specified as -libjars are also becomes part of class path for tasks.
  • Followings APIs are available to add files to distributed cache programmatically
    • public void addCacheFile(URI uri)
    • public void addCacheArchive(URI uri)
    • public void setCacheFiles(URI[] files)
    • public void setCacheArchives(URI[] archives)
    • public void addFileToClassPath(Path file)
    • public void addArchiveToClassPath(Path archive)
  • Files added to distributed cache can be private or public based on the permission set on them.

item.title: Linux - For Beginners - Part 1
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Linux is an operating system like Microsoft Windows and Mac OSX. There are multiple flavors of Linux available in market. Ubunto, Linux mint, OpenSUSE etc are some of these. The topics we will be discussing in this session will be generic and will be applicable to all flavors of Linux. For presentation sake, we will be using Ubuntu to perform our exercises. Linux operating system contains folders and files unlike to Windows where drives are defined at top level. e.g. C: drive which usually contains operating systems folders etc. One of the folder is called home and it contains the folders for each users. For example a user dummy will have its own folder in home directory as /home/dummy.

Setting Up Environment

We will be using terminal application to demonstrate all the commands given in this session.

Getting Help

First thing first, where to get help, when needed. You can find one of following three ways:

Man Pages

Most of the commands have manual pages which can be viewed in terminal by issuing man command. For example if you need to display man page for ls command, you can issue command as 
man ls

Command Help

If man page is not available, you can try help page or help command by issuing following commands 
help cd
ls --help
This session will only provide the basic commands with basic options for those commands, I highly encourage you to look into man or help pages for each of following command.

Know Your Environment

When you are  in terminal, the first thing you want to know is about your environment, e.g. where you are in directory structure, what files are in current folder, what user you are logged in with etc. Let's see those commands here:

Current Working Directory

pwd prints the full filename of the current working directory. You can issue this command as 
pwd

List Contents Of A Directory

To list the contents of a directory ls command is used. Without any option it displays the contents of current working directory. -lah are useful options where l list the content in long listing format, a displays all files by default files/folders starts with a dot (.) are hidden, h displays the size of file in human readable formate. 
ls -lah /home/

Environment Variables

variables are defined at environment level and shell level. set and env commands are used to view shell and environment variables respectively. variables defined at shell level are not visible to env command. 
set
env

Setting A Variable

Like any other programming language, variables can be assigned by using equal = operator. Subsequently, variable value can be accessed by prefixing variable name with $ sign. 
ABC=XYZ
echo $ABC

Who You Are

To find out as what user you are logged in, you can use whoami and id command. 
whoami
id
id provides more detailed information about logged in users, such as the groups this user belongs to.

Files And Directories

Once you know where you are in your systems, most of the time you will deal with files and folders. In this section, I will provide some basic commands which are used to engage with files and folders.

Changing Directory

When you are in terminal, by default you are in your home directory. You may need to change your current directory. cd command is used to change the directory. The change to path is provided to cd command. The path can be absolute or relative from current working directory. 
cd /home/user/documents/

Create New File

There are multiple ways to create a file. You can choose touch command to create zero byte file or you can use any editor to create a file. Following commands shows both version. 
touch abc.txt
vi abc.txt

Create New Directory

mkdir is used to create directories in linux. you can specify -p if a directory needs to be created but it needs to create more than one file in path hierarchy. 
mkdir -p dir1/dir2/newDir

Copy Files And Directory

cp command is used to cp files and directory from one location to another. If you are copying a directory, you would need to provide -r option. 
cp Dir1/file1 Dir2
cp -r Dir1 Dir2

mv Files And Directory

mv command is used to move files from one location to another 
mv LOC_SRC LOC_TGT

Delete Files And Directory

rm command is used to remove files and directories. Like cp command, if a directory needs to be deleted -r option needs to be provided. 
rm file1
rm -r dir1

View File Content

To view a file contents, linux provides multiple editor e.g. vi, nano etc. But if the objective is to view the file contents and not update them. less viewer can be used as 
less [filename]

Search Files

To search files in system, find command is used. find can be used in multiple ways, the most basic is to search files by name as follows: 
find SEARCH_LOC -iname FILE_NAME
find / -iname abc.txt

Security

Linux operating systems apply permissions to files and directory. This section will cover the file and folder permissions.

View Permissions

You can use ls command to view the permission of files. -l option needs to provide to view permission. 
ls -l
This command will output file/directories in long format and first column in output displays the permission of file. The first column is 10 character column such as 
drwxrwxrwx
The first character specifies if it represents a file or a directory. Next 9 characters are divided in three groups. The first three characters represent permissions for owner of the directory/file, second group of three characters represents permission for a group and third group of three characters for rest of the world.

Change Permissions

chmod is used to change the permission of files. Following example will make file.txt accessible to everyone. 
chmod 777 file.txt

Change Owner and Group

To change the owner or group of a file, following command can be used. 
chown [owner][:[group]] file

Processes

Linux manages different programs as kernel processes. This section will introduce some basic commands to view and kill processes.

View Processes

ps command is used to view the current running processes. ps accepts many options, aux are the most common options. 
ps aux

Kill Process

To kill a process you would need the process id which can be retrieved by running ps command. 
kill -9 [processId]

item.title: Apache Spark - An Introduction
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Apache Spark

Apache Spark is a hot topic these days. Companies like IBM have provided significant support this open source project by dedicating bunch of developer on this project. In this session, I will scratch the surface and will show how to start programming using Apache Spark.

Definition

From Apache Spark's website, Spark is defined as
 Apache Spark™ is a fast and general engine for large-scale data processing.

Spark Execution Model

Following diagram shows the execution model of Spark programs: [caption id="attachment_93" align="aligncenter" width="431"] Apache Spark Execution Model[/caption]

Driver

Spark Applications are initiated with Driver program. It can be your application on edge node or terminal where spark shell is started to run Spark commands.

Worker

Worker nodes are work horse where real processing happens. These are processes which can run in your local system or it can be a server node in your cluster.

Cache

This is the available memory to worker node.

Supported Languages

Currently, Spark applications can be written in Scala, Java and Python.  Apache Spark maintains APIs in all three languages.

Spark Applications

Spark application consists of follow component

SparkContext

SparkContext is the base component of spark application. Creation or retrieval of SparkContext probably will be the first step in spark applications. If spark shells (python, scala) are used to play with Spark, SparkContext is provided as variable sc.

RDD

Spark application revolves around a data structure called RDD (Resilient Distributed Dataset) which is fault-tolerant collection of elements. Once SparkContext is retrieved or created, Spark application starts creating RDDs. RDD can be created by parallelizing existing data collection in driver program or by referring a data source in local operating system or in external system. One thing to note is RDD is an immutable data structure.

Transformer

Once initial RDD is created by loading data, Spark application starts creating DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph) by applying transformations on RDDs.  Each transformation creates a new RDD as RDD is an immutable data structure. Each transformation is lazily evaluated i.e. when a transform is applied, RDD is not executed until an action is performed. Transformations are evaluated to create an DAG which will be executed. Following are some of the transformer which will be used during Spark application development.
  • textFile
  • map
  • filter
  • flatMap
  • reduceByKey
  • GroupByKey

Actions

Actions are the components which initiate the execution. Followings are some of the basic actions, which will be used during Spark application development.
  • collect()
  • first()
  • take(NUMBER_OF_RECORD)
  • count()
  • reduce()
  • saveAsTextFile()

Exercise

The video exercise for this blog can be found at Introduction To Spark My apologies to not be able to record audio but each step is self explanatory and I hope you will get most out of it.

Resources

Apache Spark documentation is number 1 resource to learn more about Spark. Along with Spark documentation, numerous books and articles are available online which you can use to learn about Spark. Keep following my blog and I will be writing more advance topics on Spark as well.

item.title: Apache HBase - Basics
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Apache HBase

Apache HBase is a distributed, scalable, low latency, random access database.

Points To Remember

  • HBase depends on Apache Zookeeper to coordinate between region server and it stores data on Apache Hadoop HDFS
  • Like any database, HBase database contains tables
  • Tables consist of rows and each row has primary (row) key.
  • Rows are sorted by row key
  • Rows consist of column family which can contain arbitrary number of column in them.
  • Each cell value is a byte array
  • ACID is guaranteed per row for HBase reads and writes by associating timestamp for each write.
  • Timestamp is the current timestamp when cell value is written but can be overridden but discouraged.
  • HBase data is stored on disk as an indexed and sorted list of cells.
  • Indexing is based on cell coordinates, row key, col, timestamp
  • Sorting allows for optimal scamming for single row read
  • Column families lay out physical separations for columns, so instead of one table, internally HBase has two tables if there are two column families.
  • Having more column families are not efficient.

Installation

HBase can be installed in cluster and local mode. Local mode is used to explore HBase capabilities. Local installation is as simple as downloading tar file and untar it in a folder. Then HBase can be started from HBase from bin directory. start-hbase.sh script is provided to start HBase.

Web Interface

Once Hbase is running, it can also starts a web application which can be accessed at port 16010. For example, if you are running HBase locally, you can access web UI at 
http://localhost:16010
 

HBase Shell

HBase Shell is a convenient way to interact with HBase database. I will be explaining some of HBase commands using HBase shell.

Run HBase Shell

To run HBase shell, run following command, I am assuming you are in bin directory of HBase installation. 
./hbase shell
To start shell in debug mode, provide -d option as 
./hbase shell -d

Getting Help

HBase shell is an interactive terminal in which you can execute command to interact with HBase. To get help about different commands, simply type help in HBase shell and hit enter. It will show you, the command you can run in shell. The commands are divided into multiple categories, e.g. general commands, dml, ddl etc. 
hbase> help
To get help for a particular category or command, pass command or category as parameter to help command. 
hbase> help 'dml'
hbase> help 'list'

List All Table

To view all the tables in HBase, run following command 
list

Create A Table

Table can be created by issuing create command. You have to specify table name and column families to create the table. If column families are not specified, a default family is created. To create a book table with info column family, following command can be issued. 
create 'book', {NAME => 'info'}

Find Table Detail

To find table detail, describe command is used. For example to find information about book table, following command is executed. 
describe 'book'

Scan A Table

To scan full table, following command can be used. 
scan 'book'
Multiple options can be passed to scan to restrict the number of results. e.g. LIMIT operator can be used to limit the number of rows. COLUMNS can be declared to get a subset of columns. Similarly STARTROW and STOPROW operators are used to restrict number of rows based on the row key value. 
scan 'book', {STARTROW => 'designPattern', LIMIT => 5}
FILTER is another valuable operator to restrict the number of result.

Retrieve A Single Row

get command is used to get a single row. table name, row key value and optionally column names can be passed. For example following command will get all the columns from book table for row value 1001 
get 'book', '1001'

Delete A Cell Value

To delete a cell value, table name, row id and column name are required to delete cell value 
delete 'book', '1001', 'book_review'

Delete A Row

If a row needs to be deleted, then deleteall command should be used. In this case, table name and row id needs to be passed 
deleteall 'book', '1001'

Next

I just covers the basics of HBase commands and I would encourage you to look into HBase documentation  for more commands.

item.title: Apache Phoenix - Relational Layer Over HBase
item.dc:creator: rashidaligee@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

So we have architected HBase system and we started using HBase by using PUT, GET, SCAN etc commands. HBase is a database system so PUT, GET and SCAN make sense to us as we have learnt HBase in columnar way. How about those who have been using relational databases using SQL or those applications which we want to back with HBase as HBase is a low latency database. There is no need to worry as Apache Phoenix provides a relational layer over HBase. In this blog, I will scratch the surface of Apache Phoenix and will perform some basic actions on HBase using Apache Phoenix.

How Apache Phoenix Works

Apache Phoenix takes your SQL query, compiles it into a series of HBase scans, and orchestrates the running of those scans to produce regular JDBC result sets. The table metadata is stored in an HBase table and versioned, such that snapshot queries over prior versions will automatically use the correct schema.

Installation

Installation of Apache Phoenix is out of scope, it is part of most Hadoop distributions but if you need are interested in installation process, visit Apache Phoenix Installation page.

SQL Support

Apache Phoenix supports a full set of DML and subset of DDL statements. Please consult documentation for more detail on sql support.

Connecting With Phoenix

JDBC

Apache Phoenix is a relational database layer so like other relational databases, Apache Phoenix can be accessed using JDBC clients. Apache Phoenix provides JDBC driver and you need to make sure Phoenix-client jar file is in path of your JDBC application. To connect to Phoenix following connection string is provide. 
jdbc:phoenix:[zookeeperQurom]:[znode]
where zookeeperQuorom: is the zookeeper quorum znode: is the znode of zookeeper, if it is not given, "hbase" is the default value.

Utilities

Apache Phoenix comes with some basic python utilities which can be used to work with Apache Phoenix. These are available in bin directory of Phoenix home directory and will be used in this blog as well.

Command Line

sqlline.py is terminal client to execute SQL commands. Along with DML and DDL commands,  SQLLine commands can be executed as well, I will encourage to look at these commands as well. You can get help for sqlline.py by running it without any parameter. In addition to sqlline.py, psql.py utility can be used to perform a bulk load into Phoenix table.

Examples

That's enough theory, let's run some queries using Apache Phoenix. I will be using sqlline.py.

CREATE Table

We will create a PERSON table which have personid, firstName and lastName columns.   CREATE TABLE person (personid bigint not null primary key, per.firstName varchar, per.lastName varchar); If everything goes fine, you will have a table. You can verify, creation of table in multiple ways.

Using sqlline commands

you can view the table by executing any of the following command. 
!tables
!describe person

Using hbase shell

If you are familiar with hbase shell, use it to find about the table because the table is created in hbase using Phoenix. 
list
scan 'PERSON'

Note:

Remember Apache Phoenix upper cases all the column and table names. see the scan statement above, I have used upper cased PERSON but when I have created the table, I have used lower case person. If you need to make is case sensitive, use quotes around table and column names.

Data Load

Now as we have table, let's insert some rows in it. Data can be loaded as bulk load using psql.py but I would continue using sqlline.py and using UPSERT statement. Run following commands one by one. 
UPSERT INTO PERSON VALUES(1, 'Rashid', 'Ali');
UPSERT INTO PERSON VALUES(2, 'John', 'Doe');
UPSERT INTO PERSON VALUES(3, 'Bruce', 'Lee');

SELECTing Data

Now let's view the data which is as easy as issue a select statement. 
SELECT * FROM PERSON;

DML Statements

I have presented some of DML statements and I encourage you to play with other statements. Reference document can be found at Phoenix Grammer
